The family feels inconvenienced by this condition. It can't afford that. Saleh strives to provide his family with their household needs. Unfortunately, his income is not enough to do that.

As a result, he turned to Al-Amal Microfinance Bank and took a loan of 200,000 YER to purchase home appliances, including a refrigerator, stove, washing machine, and other appliances. Saleh hopes to provide his family with a better future.

loans.use: to purchase home appliances.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sand, cement, and iron, as well as to pay for labor.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a 36-year-old woman who is married to Steven, who adds additional income to support their family. They are blessed with two children.  

Violet is a farmer who has been operating a cosmetics and a beauty shop business for a period of five years, earning herself an income of KES. 8,000 at the end of every month.

Violet is now servicing her second loan of KES. 45,000 with VisionFund Kenya, and intends to use this amount to buy body lotions, face creams, braids, hair chemicals, and weaving hair.

Violet plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for her children. She hopes to be a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy body lotions, face creams, braids, hair chemicals and weaving hairs.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: Oscar es un joven luchador , que culmino sus estudios secundarios mas no sus estudios superiores , por motivos de carencia economica , el actualmente trabaja en una empresa de mensajero , uno de sus sueños es poder estudiar una carrera profesional de administracion de empresas en un futuro y asi tener un mejor puesto de trabajo, el ahora se encuentra solicitando un credito para comprarle ropa a su hijo.Oscar se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamista de Kiva ya que de otorgarle el credito podra mejorar la calidad de vida de su hijo
texts.en: Oscar is a plucky young man. He completed his secondary education but, as he did not have the money, he is now working at a courier company. One of Oscar's dream is to study for a degree in business administration and in the future have a better job. Oscar is applying for a loan to buy clothes for his son. Oscar is very grateful to Kiva lenders as this loan will allow him to give his son a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy clothes for his son.

loans.name: Ángela Lourdes

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito 3 de Mayo se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.
En este lugar vive la señora Ángela, tiene 56 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció,  pero de esa relación tuvo cinco hijos mayores de edad, uno de ellos aun viven con  ella.
Doñas Ángela es una gran madre que para que a sus hijos no les falte nada se dedica al comercio, ella vende ropa interior tanto para hombres como para mujeres, camisetas, gorras y varios productos más. Trabaja  todos los días, recorre la ciudad ofreciendo sus productos, de esta forma ella se ha ganado la vida durante más de diez años, así  saco adelante a sus hijos y de esta forma aun se sigue ganando la vida. 
Este crédito lo va emplear para incrementar su negocio, en especial comprar ropa interior, camisetas, gorras y medias. Lleva tres años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos son de mucha ayuda para ella. Sus sueños son tener un local con vitrinas y bien surtido.
texts.en:
The "3 de Mayo" loan group meets every fortnight in the Picoaza parish of Portoviejo city. Picoaza is known for being a very commercial area, for its traditional festivals of Saint Peter and Saint Paul and for the people who are very joyful.

And it is here that 56-year-and Angela lives. Several years ago, Angela's husband died but she has five children, now adults, from the relationship. One of Angela's children still lives with at home.

Angela is a great mother who, in order for her children not to need for anything, has a business: she sells underwear for both men and women, as well as shirts, hats and many more products. Angela works every day, going round the city selling her products. She has made a living doing this for more than ten years. This work has allowed Angela to help her children to get ahead and she continues to earn a living in it.

This loan will be used to expand her business by buying underwear, shirts, hats and socks. Angela has been with the loan group for three years and she likes it as the loans are a great help to her. Angela's dreams are to have a well-stocked shop with display cases.

loans.use: to buy underwear, shirts, hats and socks.

loans.name: Maria Evelyn

texts.en:
Maria Evelyn is a married woman with one child. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Maria Evelyn is 50 years old now.

Maria Evelyn has a fish-vending business in the Philippines. Maria Evelyn requested a PHP 18,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

Maria Evelyn has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Maria Evelyn would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
As a married parent of ten children, Myrna works hard to support her family.

She has a fruit-vending business in the Philippines. Myrna is borrowing PHP 8,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of fruits to sell in her fruit-vending business.

Myrna has been sustaining her business activities through her past 2 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Ja'afaru

texts.en:
Ja'afaru is a maize farmer from Barau village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ja'afaru would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ja'afaru can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Ja'afaru, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To meet daily expenses so he can wait and sell his harvest at a later date for a higher price.

loans.name: Al-Shaga'a Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Shaga'a. It consists of four women  from Hodeidah city, Yemen. They have taken a loan of 360,000 YER. 

Ghazal is 52 years old and is a married woman with four children. She is an uneducated woman, but works hard to improve the living condition of her family. She has a strong determination to get ahead. Ghazal's husband was the sole breadwinner of the family. Over time, he became unable to look after the children. Ghazal decided to help him in that responsibility. 

In the beginning, she started her own business with a small amount of money, selling makeup, accessories and perfumes in order to help her husband to cover the expenses of the family. She has been running her own business for 6 years. The income of her business is very limited. Ghazal believes this business will be a profitable one for her in the future. But most of what she earns goes to cover the expenses of her family. 

She wants to expand her business more. As a result, she applied for a loan of 90,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase more accessories, makeup, perfumes, cosmetics and other items to be able to meet all the demand of her customers.

loans.use: to purchase more accessories, makeup, perfumes, cosmetics and other items.

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 47 years old. She is married with one child who is 26. She sells food stuffs and has been doing this business for 3 years. 

With the loan, she would like to buy more sorghum and maize to sell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest in same business.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum and maize to sell.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Hello, Kiva lenders! Meet Lucy, a 47-year-old, very hardworking, honest and ever smiling mother of 3 children. She lives with her husband in the Chuka area of Kenya - an area that is close to the famous Mount Kenya. Lucy passionately loves farming. She has been farming for the past 20 years and has always managed to provide for her family. Her primary source of income has been crops and some personal business that she does in order to provide food for her family. In farming, she enjoys the returns she gets but is challenged to maintain a good standard of living. Lucy has identified free space on her farm and wants to fully utilize this space by keeping a good quality dairy cow. Dairy farming in Kenya is a very profitable venture and milk prices in the recent past have been going up, so Lucy, being a visionary and entrepreneurial woman, wants to take full advantage of this. She has chosen the breed of cow that she will keep, and she knows that she will not only get milk from the cow but also manure, and this will boost the fertility of her farm. Selling her milk will never be a problem because there is a ready market and she will also be selling to big dairy processing firms. Lucy said she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they offer agricultural based loans, and their interest rate is low and is on a reducing basis. She underwent training through Juhudi Kilimo, and from this training she learned that saving is a continuous process in many microfinance institutions. Lucy hopes that through the accumulated profit she will be able to start adding value to her milk by starting services such as packaging and the production of other dairy products. This loan will change her life and will secure the future of her school-going children. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Halluru

texts.en:
Halluru is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Halluru would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Halluru can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for a price up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Halluru is looking  to earn a better income to expand his 0.2 hectare farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To pay daily expenses so he can sell his harvest later and get a higher price.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda is a married woman with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Brenda is 40 years old and all of her children are in school.

Brenda has a buy and sell coconut wine business in the Philippines. Brenda requested a 5000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional coconut wine for her business.

Brenda has been in this business for 1 year. In the future, Brenda would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional coconut wine for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy dairy cows to diversify his business, which will increase his income and eventually allow him to buy his own house.

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu is a maize farmer from Lumu village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yakubu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yakubu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Yakubu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: meet his daily expenses, eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Alfonce

texts.en:
Alfonce is a 44 year old man married to Rose, and the couple is blessed with three children.  Alfonce has been operating a retail shop for six years earning an income of KES. 15,000 at the end of every month.

Alfonce is now servicing his second loan of KES. 40,500 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to buy tea leaves, wheat flour, maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, rice and detergent.

Alfonce plans to use the anticipated profits to pay school fees to his children, and hopes to become a successful businessman with a bright future.

loans.use: To buy tea leaves, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, rice and detergents.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
It's a normal thing to have a chicken farm in Kenya, but to start an actual business out of it is something else entirely. Jane is a smallholder mixed-farmer based in Kiratina village in Thika. She is the mother of three, who has been practicing mixed farming for the last twenty years.

To earn a decent living, she makes income selling milk, poultry, greens and engaging in numerous small personal businesses. 

Only recently, she started seeing how she could be making big money off poultry farming. Raising hens to Jane is something close to a hobby. She wants to sell eggs but figures the quantity she produces won't make economic sense. She needs to purchase more poultry. However, her biggest challenge today is limited funds to expand.

Jane is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders via Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry. 

Future proceeds from the commercialization of her poultry farm are already committed to pay for her children's education. In the long run, she is confident her efforts will translate into her family having a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Jeanne D Aric

texts.en: Jean d’ arc is 48 years old. She is married with 6 children aged between 6 and 22 years, all of them go to school. She sells food and has been in a business for 10 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more beans and bananas for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beans and bananas for sale.

loans.name: Idalia María

texts.es:
El Grupo De Crédito 3 de Mayo se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.
En este lugar vive la señora Idalia, tiene 67 años de edad, está separada y de esta relación tiene cinco hijos  mayores de edad, una hija vive con ella aunque está casada y vive con su familia, también vive con su mamá la cual está muy anciana.
Doña Idalia con la intención de lograr sus propios recursos y con estos salir  adelante se dedica al comercio, ella junto  a  uno de sus yernos tienen un negocio de  compra y venta de pescado, todos los días se van hasta el mercado de mayoristas a comprar el mejor pescado, para luego llevar a vender por toda la localidad y sitios aledaños donde tienen muchos clientes, llevan en este negocio por más de 10 años con el cual salen adelante y todo lo que hacen es por el bien de la familia.
Este crédito lo va a invertir en comprar pescado. Lleva 14 años en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos han podido salir adelante. Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
The "3 de Mayo" loan group meets every fifteen days in the Picoaza parish of the city of Portoviejo, a very commercial area known also for its traditional festivities of Saint Peter and Saint Paul, and for the joy of its people. This is where Idalia lives.

Idalia is 67 years old, separated, and from the relationship she has five children, now adults. A daughter still lives with her although married and with family. Idalia also lives with her mother who is of advanced age.

With the goal of obtaining her own resources to get ahead, Idalia keeps a trade business with her son-in-law, they buy and sell fish. They arrive every day at the wholesale market to purchase the best fish and then sell all around town and in the neighboring areas where they have many clients. They've been in this business for over ten years, they make a living, and all their work is for the benefit of the family. 

She will use this loan buy fish. Idalia has been with the loan group for 14 years and she likes it, because with the loans they have been able to get ahead.

Idalia's dreams are to keep her business going.

loans.use: to buy fish.

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
This nice woman in the photo, Karine, is a teacher working at school in Verishen village. She lives with her husband and son, and both of them are employed in the private sector.
 
Besides her work in the school, Karine is also engaged in agriculture. On her farm, she keeps a cow, calves, hens and 55 colonies of bees. Near the house where the family lives, Karine also cultivates haricots and potatoes, which she sells in the local markets.
 
Karine has requested this loan of USD 2,000 to ask lenders help her with purchasing eight pigs and forage for the livestock. She relies on lenders' support and trust.

loans.use: to pay for eight pigs and forage for the livestock.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is 48 years old and has three children. Anecita is marriad and has one child in school.

Anecita is in the agricultural business in the Philippines. Anecita requested a PHP 29500 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Anecita has been doing this business for 20 years, and has borrowed 6 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Anecita would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is a maize farmer from Jaki village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Joshua would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to meet his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Joshua can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. 

Joshua, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and he hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To meet expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Teya

texts.en:
Teya is 24 years old. She is not married. 

She has a shop and has been doing a business for two years. 

With the loan, she would like to buy more saucepans, plates, etc. for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more saucepans, plates, etc. for sale.

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Roda. She lives in the Litein area of Kenya, renowned for its rolling hills carpeted in manicured tea plantations. Leah is a mother of four children and she has been in the agriculture business for 16 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, and tea. 

Roda has been relying on agriculture to make all her income. However, rising costs of farming inputs, such as fertilizers, and fluctuations in market prices are some of the serious challenges that are cutting farmers' profits significantly. Despite these tough conditions, Roda remains positive and passionate about her economic activity. 

Roda is seeking a loan to purchase poultry. This will enable her to expand the section of business least affected by harsh external conditions. Poultry farming is cheaper to run and the demand for chicken products is always high. 

With this loan, Roda will be able to increase the sales from her poultry business and make more profits. An increase in income for her is timely since it will enable her to tackle high farm-related costs next season. This will greatly improve the quality of work since the cost of every input will be adequately met. As a result, she will realize better quality produce and more yields. This loan will support Roda’s economic activity, and will change her family’s living standards indirectly.

loans.use: To buy poultry.

loans.name: Nelli

texts.en:
Nelli, the nice woman in the photo, lives in Artik town. She lives there with her husband, mother-in-law, and two children (17-year-old son and 16-year-old daughter).  With the great help of her husband, Nelli takes care of a cow, 4 calves and cultivates wheat and potatoes. They earn income from the sale of meat and gathered harvest of wheat and potatoes. 
Nelli has requested this loan to buy fertilizer and forage for feeding the livestock in winter. This loan will be a big support for Nelli and her farm, so she will be prepared for the winter season.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer and forage for feeding the livestock in the winter

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sand, cement, re-bar, zinc laminate and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 42 years old. She is married with 3 children aged between 14 and 19 years, all of them go to school. She has a shop and has been running her business for 10 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more salt, sugar, rice and soap for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more salt, sugar, rice and soap for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to be able to divide her house into rooms to guarantee more comfort and privacy.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and manure for his crops.

loans.name: Donabel

texts.en:
Donabel is a 24-year-old married woman with one child in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Donabel has had a food vending business for 2 years and requests 6,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

In the future, Donabel would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Virginie

texts.en:
Virginie is a 36-year-old married woman with 3 children between the ages of  3 and 10; 2 attend school. 

She has been a tailor for 1 year. With the loan, she would like to buy clothes to tailor. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is a 61-year-old widow with nine children. Editha works very hard to provide for them.

Editha has run a general store for 16 years and requests 11,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase canned goods, beverages, and shampoo.

In the future, Editha would like to save enough money to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase  canned goods, beverages, and shampoo.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a wife, mother, and  farmer with 15 years experience in mixed farming. She lives in Litein, Kenya with her seven children on a small piece of land that she inherited from her parents.

Ruth completed high school thanks to the financial support and effort of her parents. She has the spirit to succeed in life and sells  milk, eggs, and a variety of crops to the local market and neighbors. She passionately loves poultry farming and as she likes to say “poultry is close to my heart”. 

Although this humble and ever smiling mother makes a profit selling poultry, she  lacks the funds to buy good quality breeds of poultry and expand her farm. She requests a loan to buy poultry. She has identified good breeds of poultry that will increase productivity and produce quality meat. Ruth has enough feed to give the poultry energy and green grams to give the poultry protein. This will assure increased productivity. 

She chose to join Juhudi Kilimo so that she can have access to quality loans at an affordable interest rate. She will use the loan to improve her living conditions and purchase  chicken manure. She will save a lot of cash that could have been spent on buying fertilizer. 

This loan will be a turning point in Ruth’s life since she will improve her living standards and secure the future of her children.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: Estrellas Group

texts.es:
Nieves es una mujer de 38 años de edad, viuda, tiene tres hijos de 14, 11 y 5 años de edad, y su negocio es la venta de juguetes.
Ella es buena madre, responsable, constante, independiente y trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘plan 3000’ un lugar caracterizado por el creciente comercio en todas las áreas generado por migrantes mineros relocalizados de occidente y tribus indígenas del lugar como los ‘Ayoreos’, de clima cálido, húmedo y tropical con una temperatura constante entre 27-32 grados centígrados durante todo el año.
Nieves es de tez morena, cabello negro largo trenzado, estatura mediana, su forma de vestir es tradicional (pollera, manta y sombrero), su lengua materna es el Quechua y habla español (al centro, usa pollera con flores rosada, suéter negro, mandil azul). Su vida la realiza con sus tres hijos, los dos mayores estudian en la escuela y el menor se encuentra a su cuidado, viven en una casa propia de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable y luz eléctrica. Debido a la necesidad de mejorar sus ingresos y aprovechar las ventas de fin de año, conformó una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de mandiles, venta de camisetas y pantalones cortos, venta de polleras, venta de ropa para niños, taller de costura, venta de jugos batidos y servicio de té, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus actividades. Su negocio es la venta de juguetes infantiles, como: Angry Birds, Barbie, Beanie Ballz, Caillou, Disney Aviones, Disney Figuras, Dora la Exploradora, Dragones, Educativos, Furby, Juegos de Cartas, Juguetes de Bebé, etc. en un puesto de venta fijo. Ella conoce por su experiencia que las ventas a fin de año de sus productos se duplican generando mejores ingresos para su familia. Su sueño es tener un negocio estable, y desea realizar la compra por mayor de juguetes surtidos para aprovechar las ventas de fin de año. Esta es la tercera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en ocho años que viene realizando esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Nieves solicita un préstamo para la compra de juguetes surtidos por mayor para aprovechar las ventas de fin de año y con los beneficios pagar los gastos de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Nieves is a 38 year old widow who has 3 children aged 14, 11 and 5 years old. Her business is selling toys. She is a good mother, responsible, consistent, independent and hard-working. Her business is located in the 'Plan 3000' zone, an area known for it's growing commerce in all areas generated by migrant miners relocating from the west and native tribes from the area such as the ‘Ayoreos’. It's climate is hot, humid and tropical with a temperature that hovers between 27 and 32 degrees centigrade all year.

Nieves is dark-skinned with long black hair done in a braid and medium stature. She dresses in the traditional way with a skirt, blanket and hat. Her native language is Quechua and she speaks Spanish. (She is in the center of the photo with a red flower skirt, black sweater and blue apron. She lives her life with her 3 children. The two oldest study in school and she looks after for the youngest. She lives in her own brick house that has running water and electricity.

Due to the need to increase her income and take advantage of the end of the year sales she joined a group of people with businesses like selling aprons, selling shirts and short pants. Selling polleras (skirts), the sale of children's clothing, a sewing workshop, selling blended juices, and serving tea, to request a loan to improve their businesses.

Nieves sells children's toys like Angry Birds, Barbie, Beanie Balls, Caillou, Disney Airplanes, Disney Figures, Dora the Explorer, Dragons, Educational games, Furby, card games, Juguetes de Bebé, etc. She has a stand. Shew knows from experience that her sales at the end of the year double generating greater income for her family. Her dream is to have a stable business. She wants to make the purchase of a variety of toys to take advantage of the end of the year.

This is her third loan from the institution in her 8 years in business. For these reasons Nieve is requesting a loan to buy a variety of toys wholesale to take advantage of the end of year sales. With the profits she will pay for the expenses of her children.

loans.use: to buy a variety of toys to take advantage of the sales at the end of the year and be able to pay the expenses of her children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make her tuition payment at the Institute.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is 34 years old and has four children. three attend school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Elsa has had a food vending business for 3 years. Elsa requests 6,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Elsa has been in this business for 3 years. In the future, Elsa would like to save enough money  to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 44 years old and married with three children. All of her children are in school, and Christine works very hard to provide for them.

Christine runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, groceries, etc.

Christine has been in this business for two years now. 

In the future, Christine would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, groceries, etc

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda is 58 years old and married with four children. One of her children is in school. Gilda works very hard to provide for them.

Gilda runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, groceries, etc.

Gilda has been in this business for two years. 

In the future, Gilda would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 27 years old. She is married with two children aged 11 months and 5 years; one of them goes to school. She sells vegetables and has been working in a business for two years. 

After getting her loan, she would like to buy onions, carrots and cabbages for sale. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption and reinvested.

loans.use: to buy onions, carrots and cabbages for sale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Lenders! Meet Margaret, a hardworking mother of two children who has been doing farming for the last 31 years so that she can supplement her income from the small profits she gets from a personal businesses. Margaret does crop farming and cattle keeping, and she enjoys farming a lot. 

Her biggest challenges are a lack of finances to improve her farming and diseases. This has made her seek a loan of 30,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to purchase another goat. With this goat, her projections are that by the end of the year, the goat would have given birth to at least four other goats. Through goat keeping, she will be able to get goat milk, which is very expensive and fetches more profits. This translates to more income and improved living conditions for her family. Also, she will be able to sell goat meat and goat skin, which will be increasing her income level. The profits will be used to repay the loan on time and grow the business.

loans.use: to buy another goat

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a maize farmer from Chiroma village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Peter would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Peter can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Peter, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access a loan that meets expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ibrahim G.

texts.en:
Ibrahim G. is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim G. would have had to sell his  maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Ibrahim G. can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked about his goals, Ibrahim G. expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access a loan that meets expenses like clothing and food, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Danyaro

texts.en:
Danyaro is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Danyaro joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Aliyu, Habibu and Shaibu.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Danyaro would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Danyaro can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Danyaro  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like child school fees and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Balarabe

texts.en:
Balarabe is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Balarabe joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Habubakar, Usamatu and Idi.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Balarabe would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Balarabe can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Balarabe  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like child school fees and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sand, cement, metal, gravel and pay for manual labor costs.

loans.name: Ragheb

texts.en:
Ragheb is a 24-year-old single hard working man, who has been a hairdresser since 2009. Ragheb doesn't have a permanent working place, but visits his customers's at their homes and provides them with the requested beauty services.  He also works with several beauty salons that set appointments with him on a weekly basis to meet customers' needs.

Ragheb is making his dream come true and requests a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua  to open his own beauty salon. He will be able to treat his loyal customers in a special pampering way and provide them with the requested beauty services.

He has always dreamed of having a beauty center and he is excited about this loan. He sees this as a step forward and will make sure to succeed.

loans.use: to open his own Beauty salon.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is a married woman with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Gina is 49 years old, and one child is in school.

Gina has a food-vending business in the Philippines. It was damaged by super typhoon Haiyan last November 8, 2013. Gina requested a 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) bridge loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-production business to restart her business activities.

Gina has been in this business for three years and would like to rebuild it with your help. In the future, Gina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-production business

loans.name: Agape Group

texts.en:
Hannah is the representative of this group, Agape. Her group is located in Chorkor, Accra. She makes her home here in Chorkor with her husband and two children. The group is into jeans, slippers, second-hand clothing, general goods, pork, fast food, toothbrush and toothpaste sales. 

Hannah is excited to be taking her sixth loan from ID-Ghana after having successfully repaid her previous loans and expanding her business. She has had her business for 10 years, starting with her first loan, with which she bought a few jeans, and sold them to customers. 

Hannah plans to use this loan to invest in her businesses to increase her inventory by purchasing more jeans and slippers from the main market and selling them to customers. Hannah will use the profits to reinvest in her businesses and provide for her family, thus helping her partner. She wants to build her own house and have all her family together in a better house. 

The group will need a total amount of 8,300 GHS to buy enough and serve customers better.

loans.use: to purchase more jeans and slippers from the main market and sell them to customers.

loans.name: Khamal

texts.en:
Khamal is a maize farmer from Kwalo village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Khamal would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Khamal can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Khamal, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Kotognogotala Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe KOTOGNOGOTA ont en moyenne 37 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à TALO/SEGOU (la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des produits divers, des céréales et des condiments. Les femmes du groupe KOTOGNOGOTA sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire. BINTOU, 2ème femme debout  la droite vers la gauche sur la photo ;  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter  100 plateaux, 100 tasses ; 100 assiettes, 50 louches, 50 pots tous en plastiques. Elle s’approvisionne à Ségou et souvent à Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, à la nourriture, à l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group called Kotognogotala have an average age of 37 and on average four children, and they all live in traditional extended families in Talo/Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women met because they are related and they buy and sell various home products, cereals, and condiments.  

The women from the group called Kotognogotala are on their first solidarity loan. Bintou, the second woman standing from right to left in the photo, intends to use her loan to buy 100 trays, 100 cups, 100 plates, 50 ladles, and 50 little pots, all made of plastic. She buys her wares in  Ségou and often in Bamako. She makes her sales to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash and often on credit. 

Bintou expects to make an average monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which will be used for expenses relative to health, food, clothing, and school fees. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy various home products for resale

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
Haruna is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Haruna joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Clion, Noel and Samsin.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Haruna would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Haruna can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Haruna  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to pay for a place to store his maize.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma is 32 years old and has six children, all attend school.  Erma works very hard to provide for them.

Erma has run a general store for 5 years and requests 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase canned goods, beverages, and cigarettes.

She sells a variety of items such as rice, soft drinks, soap, and seasonings. 

In the future, Erma would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, beverages, and cigarettes.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 43-year-old married woman with 3 children between the ages of 10 and 19, all attend school. 

She has had a shop  for 5 years. She will use the loan to buy more sugar, maize flour, and rice to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for the family and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, maize flour, and rice.

loans.name: Rahila

texts.en:
Rahila is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Rahila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Yusuf, Hajjara and Saminu.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Rahila would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. 

She will use this loan to buy a place to store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Rahila  will use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase a place to store maize.

loans.name: Samar Group

texts.en:
Samar is the featured borrower for Samar Group. She got together with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. They are working hard to develop their businesses and living at the same time.

Samar is a 31-year-old married mother of two children. Due to the low financial situation of her husband, she started selling clothes to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family.

Today, Samar is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise with a new winter collection to satisfy her customers and attract new ones.

Samar is the first lady on the right. With respect to the other group members, Mervat is the lady standing in the middle, and Sahar is the first lady on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with a new winter collection

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Glenda is 44 years old and one of her children is in school.

Glenda has a buy-and-sell coconut wine business in the Philippines. Glenda requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional containers of coconut wine to sell.

Glenda has been in this business for one year. In the future, Glenda would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional containers of coconut wine to sell

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.ru: Гульсара, 46 лет, замужем, мать 5 детей. В качестве источника дохода для своей семьи, она занимается животноводством и полеводством, начав этот бизнес 18 лет назад с собственных сбережений. Благодаря упорному труду Гульсары, ее бизнес на сегодняшний день насчитывает 1 корову и 33 овцы, также на участке мерою 1,09 Га она выращивает пшеницу для внутрихозяйственного потребления и реализации. Вся деятельность позволяет ей иметь прибыль в сумме 12,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гульсара обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 45,000 сом (KGS) на покупку одной коровы. Доходы от кредита она планирует вложить в дальнейшее расширение бизнеса и накопить средства на образование ее детей.
texts.en: Gulsara is 46 years old, married and the mother of five. As a main source of income for her family, she raises livestock and grows farm produce, having launched this business 18 years ago with her own savings. Thanks to Gulsara’s hard work, she now has one cow and 33 sheep on her farm. In addition, she has a land plot of 1.09 ha, where she grows wheat for own consumption and sale. Altogether her business brings in a revenue of 12,000 KGS per month. In order to develop her business further, Gulsara has turned to the Bai Tushum microfinance institution for a loan in the amount of 45,000 KGS to buy one cow. She plans to invest the revenues from this loan in an additional expansion of her business and to save up for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase one cow in order to invest in further growth of her business and pay for her children's education.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is 21 years old and has three children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Josefina has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 6,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Josefina has been in this business for two years. In the future, Josefina would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Helene

texts.fr:
Mme HELENE est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Le plus âgé a 23ans et le moins âgé a 06ans. Tous vont  à l'école. Elle a 07personnes en charge.
Mme vend des légumes depuis 05ans. Elle s'approvisionne dans le marché de son quartier. 
Elle veut s'acheter 01sac d’oignon, ½  sac de choux, ½ sac d’aubergine et 04 paquets de cube Maggie.
Mme veut agrandir son activité avec ses bénéfices. Elle ambitionne payer la scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
Mme Helene is married and the mother of four children. The oldest is 23 and the youngest six years old. They all go to school. Helene is responsible for seven persons. 

Helene has been selling vegetables for five years. She buys her wares in the marketplace in her neighborhood.  She wants to buy one sack of onions, 1/2 sack of cabbages, 1/2 sack of eggplant, and four packets of Maggi cubes. 

Helen would like to expand her business with her profit. Her ambition is to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy one sack of onions, 1/2 sack of cabbages, 1/2 sack of eggplant, and four packets of Maggi cubes

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 37 years old and married with three children. With two children in school, Joy works very hard to provide for them.

Joy's business was devastated by super typhoon Haiyan that swept through the Philippines on November 8, 2013. Joy is taking out a bridge loan to restart her general store business.

Joy has requested PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to restart her general store business.

She is using the new loan to stock up on a variety of goods to resell. 

Joy is committed to rebuild, and in the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to stock up on a variety of goods to restart her little store that was devastated by typhoon Haiyan.

loans.name: Shahida

texts.en:
Shahida is a 42-year-old married woman, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of eight children and equally responsible for all of them. 
She belongs to an ultra-poor family and that is why she cannot afford their educational expenses. Most of her children are doing jobs as laborers for daily wages. 

One of her sons goes with his father to help him in his business. Her husband owns a blacksmith shop in which he provides welding services. He also provides door-to-door services to his customers. Due to the increase in the price of iron, he is unable to buy sufficient welding material such as welding rods, soldering rods, etc. to carry on his business.

To fulfill the demand of his customers and to run his enterprise, he needs some capital to buy welding materials. Shahida has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan for her husband so that he would be able to buy welding rods, soldering rods and iron rods for manufacturing iron accessories.

Shahida is very glad and thankful to Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy welding rods, soldering rods and iron rods for manufacturing iron accessories.

loans.name: Justine

texts.fr: Justine est divorcée et mère d’un enfant. Elle vit dans le quartier Adidogomé Avatamé.Elle tient une boutique à domicile et  vend des charbons et de petits sachets d’eau minérale. Très dynamique, elle s’approvisionne au marché du Nord du TOGO auprès des fermiers. Par manque de fonds de roulement, elle s’y rend 02 fois par mois.Afin d’augmenter son stock, elle sollicite ce microcrédit pour acheter 02 sacs de charbon et 40 sachets d’eau minérale.
texts.en:
Justine is divorced and the mother of one child. She lives in the neighborhood called Adidogomé Avatamé. She has a little shop in her house and sells charcoal and little bags of mineral water. Very dynamic, she buys her supplies in a market in the north of Togo, from farmers. Because she lacks working capital, she goes there twice a month. 

In order to add to her inventory, Justine is asking for this small loan to buy two sacks of charcoal and 40 bags of mineral water.

loans.use: to buy two sacks of charcoal and 40 bags of drinking water, "Pure Water"

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Lerma is 57 years old now.

Lerma has a food vending business in the Philippines. It was damaged by super typhoon Haiyan last November 8, 2013. Lerma requested a 5,000 PHP bridge loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her business so she can restart her business activities.

Lerma has been in this business for three years and would like to rebuild it with your help. In the future, Lerma would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to continue with house construction which will guarantee comfort and privacy for her children.

loans.name: Espoir Group

texts.fr: La cliente MULASI est agée de 38 ans, mère de 5 enfants tous étudiants. Veuve de son état, elle est présidente du groupe de crédit ESPOIR.Elle s’occupe de la vente des boissons  à son domicile, activité qu’elle a débuté en 2009 grâce au premier prêt de HEKIMA. Ave c le nouveau prêt, elle compte agrandir son entreprise en s’approvisionnant de 400 casiers d’amstel, 20 casiers de Primus, 10 casiers de sucré et payer le transport, malgré le problème d’inflation que connait la monnaie nationale. Son objectif c'est de prosperer dans les affaires. Elle remercie ainsi HEKIMA, pour son soutien.
texts.en: The client named Mulasi is 38 years old and has five children who all attend school. She is a widow and president of the credit group Espoir. She sells beverages from home. She started this business in 2009 thanks to a first loan from Hekima. With this new loan, she plans to expand her business by stocking up with 400 crates of Amstel, 20 crates of Primus, 10 crates of sweet drinks and paying the transport for these supplies. This, in spite of the inflation that her national currency is subject to at present. Her aim is to do well in business. She thanks Hekima for their support.

loans.use: to expand her business by stocking up with 400 crates of Amstel, 20 crates of Primus, 10 crates of sweet drinks and paying the transport for these supplies.

loans.name: Monique Abla

texts.fr: Monique a 27 ans. Elle est divorcée et vit avec son enfant dans le quartier Wonyomé. Depuis 2012, elle a commencé son commerce de parfum et des sacs. A cause de la mévente, elle oriente son commerce dans la vente des sous-vêtements hommes et femmes. Elle vend à la criée dans les marchés et à son domicile.Monique sollicite ce microcrédit pour acheter respectivement 12 douzaine de slips pour femme et 12 douzaines et demie pour enfants.Le profit lui permettra de payer les frais de scolarité de son enfant et d’assurer son bien-être.
texts.en: Monique is 27. She is divorced and lives with her child in the Wonyome district. She started her business selling perfume and bags in 2012. Due to the slump in sales, she has changed her business and now sells undergarments for men and women. She sells her goods by hawking at local markets and from her home. Monique requests this micro-credit to buy supplies, specifically 12 dozen pairs of pants for ladies, 12 dozen pairs of pants for men and 12 and a half-dozen for children. The profit will enable her to pay school fees for her child and ensure her well-being.

loans.use: to buy 25 dozen pairs of pants (for women and children).

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita has four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. She is 44 years old and one of her children is in school.

Florita runs a manicure/pedicure business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 2 years. She has requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more materials for her business.

In the future, Florita would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase organic inputs for his cacao crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to fertilise and maintain his cocoa crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an industrial sewing machine in order to work better.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is a 46-year-old married woman with eight children, four of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Lolita has a food vending business in the Philippines, but it was damaged by super typhoon Haiyan last November 8, 2013. She was in this business for 1 year, and would now like to rebuild it with your help.

She has requested a PHP 5,000 bridge loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business so she can restart her business activities.

In the future, Lolita would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Lourdes is 43 years old, and all of her children are in school.

Lourdes has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional materials to use in her food stall.

Lourdes has been in this business for one year. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials to use in her food stall

loans.name: Ma. Aileen

texts.en:
Ma. Aileen is 35 years old and married with four children. All of her children are in school; she works very hard to provide for them.

Ma. Aileen runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, eggs, canned goods, etc..

Ma. Aileen has been in this business for one year. 

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, eggs, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, canned goods, eggs, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
Teresa, ha logrado mantener la venta de tortillas, leña y cosméticos en el mercado con la ayuda del préstamo anterior, da a su familia una vida más digna y tiene nuevos clientes. 
Como no cuenta con el capital suficiente para tener materia prima para elaborar la venta, se decidió por solicitar un nuevo crédito para comprar una plancha industrial, leña, maíz y variedad cosméticos, con esta inversión mejorara su negocio y seguirá trabajando.
texts.en:
Teresa has been able to continue selling tortillas, firewood and cosmetics in the market with the help of the previous loan. She has been able to give her family a more dignified life and she has new customers. 

As she does not have enough capital to get the raw materials needed to make her products, she has decided to ask for a new loan in order to buy an industrial grill, firewood, maize and various cosmetics. With this investment she will be able to improve her business and continue working.

loans.use: to buy an industrial grill, firewood, maize and various cosmetics.

loans.name: Mardessa

texts.en:
Mardessa is 23 years old and has one child in school. She works very hard to provide for her child.

Mardessa runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like condiments, canned goods, eggs, groceries, etc. She has been in this business for 2 years. 

In the future, Mardessa would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like condiments, canned goods, eggs, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Usuman

texts.en:
Usuman is a maize farmer from Yalwan Pegi village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Usuman would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Usuman can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Usuman, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to pay for expenses like food and clothing, eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a maize farmer from Chiroma village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Maryamu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Maryamu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Maryamu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to pay for expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Le'atu Philibus

texts.en:
Le'atu Philibus is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Le'atu Philibus would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to her immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Le'atu Philibus can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Le'atu Philibus, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to ensure that her children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to access meet expenses like food and clothing; eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Manessa Group

texts.en:
Majeda is the featured borrower for Manessa Group. She, along with her other group members, take this Al Majmoua group loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. They are working hard to develop their businesses and to manage living expenses at the same time.

Majeda is a 49-year-old married mother of three children who started tailoring twenty four years ago  to help her husband, who has a limited salary, in covering for the needs and expenses of their family. Majeda is trying desperately to provide her family with better living conditions. Today, she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field Partner Al Majmoua to pay her son's school tuition fees.

Majeda is the lady standing in the middle. With respect to the other group members, Nahed is the lady standing on the right, and Rima is the lady standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to pay her son's school tuition fees.

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es:
María Teresa tiene 29 años de edad, es conviviente, con dos hijos a su cargo, vive en casa propia, en una zona rural del distrito de Oyotún, provincia de Chiclayo, región Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú. Su comunidad está dedicada básicamente a la agricultura, ganadería y al comercio.

María Teresa se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales de corral, hace 6 años, negocio se encuentra ubicado en su domicilio, solicita préstamo para capital de trabajo; compra de cuyes, patos, gallina, pavos; para poder aumentar y diversificar su stock; el préstamo le ayudará para tener una mayor inversión, esto con la finalidad de incrementar su negocio de los mismos y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes. Lo que le permitirá en un corto plazo mejorar sus ingresos, aumentar sus ganancias y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Maria Teresa is 29 years old. She lives with her partner and her two children. She lives in her own house, in a rural area in the district of Oyotun, province of Chiclayo, region of Lambayeque, north coast of Peru. The main occupations in the community are basically agriculture, livestock, and commerce.

Maria Teresa raises and sells farm animals. She is being doing this for 6 years. Her business is located in her home. She is requesting the loan to invest the money in her work. She'll buy guinea pigs, ducks, hens, turkeys, to be able to increase and diversify her stock.

The loan will help her make a bigger investment to increase her business and satisfy her clients' needs. In a short period of time she'll improve her income, increase the profits, and finally will improve her family's life.

loans.use: to invest the money to buy guinea pigs, ducks, hens, and turkeys.

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar is 48 years old and married, with four children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Maricar runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, groceries, etc..

Maricar has been in this business for five years now. 

In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
María, utiliza los créditos como herramientas para crecer con su negocio y mejorar su situación económica, con la ayuda facilitada anteriormente María obtuvo una cosecha abundante y las ganancias han mejorado, su familia vive en mejores condiciones.
Requiere de un nuevo capital para comprar tres cerdos e insumos agrícolas para fortalecer su negocio, tendrá alimento para su familia, abastecerá a sus clientes y con la venta de cerdos sus ganancias aumentaran.
texts.en: María uses her loans as tools to better herself along with her business and improve her financial situation. The assistance she received previously allowed her to obtain a plentiful harvest and increase her profits. Her family lives under better conditions. She is in need of a new loan to purchase three pigs and farming supplies to improve her business. This will enable her to feed her family, supply her clients, and improve her profits through the sale of pigs.

loans.use: to buy three pigs and farming supplies to improve her business.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel has ten children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Maricel is 42 years old, and five of her children are in school.

Maricel has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell.

Maricel has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu is 32 years old and has three children. Two of her children are in school, and Marichu works very hard to provide for them.

Marichu runs a general store in the Philippines, and has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell, such as beverages, eggs, shampoo, etc.

Marichu has been in this business for 1 year. 

In the future, Marichu would like to build and expand her business to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like beverages, eggs, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Nadya

texts.en: Nadya is from Azatamut village in the Tavush region, where she lives with her husband and her son. Her son is an army officer. Nadya, with the help of her husband, runs a farm. They are mainly involved in breeding cattle. Unfortunately, because of a number of recurring costs, Nadya and her husband are not able to save money to purchase a barn for their livestock. That's the reason Nadya has applied for this loan. She asks lenders to support her and help her purchase a new barn. This hardworking woman, with perfect credit history, hopes for your goodwill and support.

loans.use: to pay for a new barn for her cattle

loans.name: Suraja

texts.en:
Suraja is a maize farmer from Kankanki village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Suraja would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Suraja can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Suraja, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing; eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Rafkatu

texts.en:
Rafkatu is a maize farmer from Chiroma village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Rafkatu would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Rafkatu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Rafkatu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 17 years old and lives in the town of Iganga, in the Iganga region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past three years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her clothing business, in which she sells old clothes. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of UGX 600,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and will help Sarah to generate and earn greater profits. Sarah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to build a permanent house. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Victoria's Group

texts.en:
Victoria's group is comprised of 4 hard working women. Victoria is 18 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Victoria has been working hard to manage her food stall business, where she sells vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Victoria has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more tomatoes, cabbage, and onions, and will help Victoria to generate greater profits and provide for her family. Victoria hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a restaurant. 

Victoria is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more tomatoes, cabbage, and onions

loans.name: Giovany Patriccio

texts.es: Giovany es un joven emprendedor que acaba de terminar la secundaria y sueña poder costearse sus estudios superiores ya que su familia no tiene las posibilidades economicas para apoyarlo , el desea estudiar marketing,negocios internacionales y poder realizarce profesionalmente , una de sus metas es llegar a tener su propia empresa.Inicialmente el desea vender ropa y zapatillas, para ello el esta solicitando un credito que le permita comprar mercaderia e iniciar su negocio propio.Giovany esta muy agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que de brindarle el credito el podria iniciar con sus proyectos y con ello generar ingresos para cumplir con sus sueños.
texts.en:
Giovany is a young entrepreneur who finished his Secondary school studies and dreams of being able to afford higher education as his family doesn't have the economic possibilities to support him. He wants to study marketing and International business and become a professional.

One of his goals is to have his own business. Initially he wanted to sell clothing and shoes. So he is requesting this loan to allow him to buy merchandise and start his own business. Giovany is very grateful to the lenders at Kiva as offering him this loan he can begin his projects and with it generate income to fulfill his dreams.

loans.use: to buy clothing to sell.

loans.name: Basiru

texts.en:
Basiru is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Basiru would have had to sell his  maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Basiru can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked about his goals, Basiru expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, ensure other members  of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: To pay for expenses like clothing and food, thereby eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
After spending three years in the jewelry wholesale business, Maria decided she wanted to reduce her travel and found a spot in a local mall that would be perfect for her to sell jewelry. 

Maria’s jewelry experience extends back to her time in Mexico, where she was a wholesaler as well as a store owner. Maria says, “I love the business of jewelry, and I know there is so much more I can do in my store.” Maria lives with her husband and daughter; her husband helps to take care of the store.

Maria needs a loan to buy more inventory, ensuring she has the special pieces customers are looking for. She also would like to buy a register and invest in a marketing plan. 

Maria’s vision for the future is “to generate enough income so I can pay myself, hire two employees, and grow my business by doing more marketing-related tasks."

loans.use: to buy more jewelry and a new register.

loans.name: Jose Alfredo

texts.es:
José, invirtió el préstamo anterior en el mejoramiento del inventario de la venta de productos varios en su vehículo, teniendo con ello nuevos clientes, un aumento en las ventas y ganancias, las que le sirven para cubrir los gastos familiares. Actualmente ya estableció una tienda en su casa de habitación y en su vehículo realiza viajes.
Con las nuevas demandas de sus clientes el negocio debe ofrecer nuevos productos por lo que se ha decidido por un nuevo crédito, con el que comprará granos básicos, bebidas, golosinas, harinas, especias, etc., dará mejor atención a sus clientes y mantendrá su fidelidad.
texts.en: José invested his previous loan improving the inventory of products he sells from his vehicle. He won new clients and increased sales and profits, which have enabled him to pay for household expenditures. He has now established a store in his house and currently uses his vehicle for transportation. To satisfy the needs of his new clients, he must offer new products. Thus, he decided to request a new loan, which he will use to purchase basic grains, drinks, candy, flour, spices, etc., provide better customer service and maintain his performance.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, drinks, candy, flour, spices, etc., provide better customer service and maintain his performance.

loans.name: Ruelita

texts.en:
Ruelita is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Ruelita is 51 years old and one of her children is in school.

Ruelita has a vegetables vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 8000 loan amount through NWTF to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall.

Ruelita has been in this business for 2 years. In the future, she would like to build and expand her business to secure the future for her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Josyline

texts.en:
Hello world, meet Josyline. Josyline is a hard-working, small-scale farmer in Chuka, which is a small, rural town in the coffee-growing region of Kenya. 

For the last five years of her life, Josyline has been doing mixed farming. This has worked out well for her since she has been able to provide a decent living for her five children. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, and crops. 

Josyline is seeking a loan to construct a dairy shed. This will provide shelter for her favorite animal, named Karimi. The thing she enjoys most about dairy farming is selling milk. However, in order for a dairy cow to be more productive, the farmer needs to be good at dairy management. Your loan will help Josyline construct a cowshed that will help very much with dairy management. The shelter will enable her to prepare food rations and feed the cow. The shed will also ensure the cow is always in a clean and hygienic environment. 

Your loan will bring untold benefits to Josyline. She is projecting a significant increase in milk production. The extra money will go to loan repayment and her children’s education. Her dream is for her children to live a better life with fulfilled, basic needs.

loans.use: to construct a modern dairy shed.

loans.name: Manira

texts.en:
Manira is from Hovit village, Shirak region. She lives with her family (husband and two children) and her brother-in-law and his wife. 

Manira is involved in agriculture together with her family members. On their farm, they keep livestock (cows, calves, sheep, hens) and cultivate wheat, beetroot and apple and pear trees. 

Manira has now applied for this loan to be able to purchase four calves and forage for feeding the livestock. 

Some years ago, the farm that Manira and her family owned was big and profitable. After financial difficulties that the family faced, they had to sell a big part of their livestock.  

Now they hope to develop their farm further and make it sustainable again.

loans.use: to pay for four calves and forage for feeding the livestock

loans.name: Malami

texts.en:
Malami is a maize farmer from Barau village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Malami would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater to his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Malami can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvesting time. 

Malami, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing; eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time.

loans.name: Maa Dangar Budi Group

texts.en:
Dangarbudi is a Joint Liability Group formed by thirteen active women entrepreneurs of Kandei village of Balangir district in Odisha, India to access a loan from Mahashakti Foundation and expand their businesses. This village is situated in a rural area which is around 150 kilometers away from the district headquarters. Cultivation is the main source of income of the people of this village. Apart from this a few families have small enterprises to earn some additional income for better livelihood. Hemalata is one of them. She is 33 years of age and hails from a Below Poverty Line family. The lady standing raising her hand in the photo is Hemalata. 

Hemalata felt that the income from cultivation was not at all sufficient for managing her family, so for the last three years she has been running a general store in her house. Her husband helps in her business, for example doing the marketing from the nearest town. She sells general grocery items like sugar, lentils, biscuits, soap, shampoo, potatoes, onions, etc. 

Hemalata was able to increase the variety of items at her general store with her scanty savings and increase her cash flow. Her monthly income from the existing business is Rs.3000. From this income she barely manages her household expenses. Due to this lesser amount of income she is not able to construct a house for her family. So she wants to increase the stock of her business to earn some more income. 

The present loan amount of Hemalata will be utilized to purchase items like rice, wheat, lentils, oil, etc. for her general store. This will help her to reduce her purchasing and transportation costs as she will replenish her stock frequently. She is also very much hopeful that this investment will help her to generate some additional income and she can plan for a bright future.
